comments.commentBody: Leave it to the players to decide?  In 1993, while playing for the Red Sox, Dawson was asked which team's cap he would want to wear if he ever made it to the Hall of Fame.  He stated clearly that he would choose the team that gave him a chance to play when others -- the Expos and the Cubs -- had given up on him.  He said then that he wanted to wear a Red Sox cap to the Hall.

I enjoyed this puzzle tonight and did not have any of the troubles of the past few days.  I recently watched 'No Country for Old Men,' so I had the Pardoner's Tale in mind, which helped.  I recall we had a cigar clue recently, so that wasn't a problem when I saw the A at the end of the thin smoke.  I saw a WALCOTT play on Broadway and learned about Salvador Agron.  Paul Simon did the music for The Capeman which I found better than the story.  I did not know AMADIS, but it sounds like he did not respect doctors.

I am ecstatic! First time EVER to finish a Saturday completely on my own!
(which means everyone will write in and say how easy it was lol)

Shoofly pie....a gimme for someone who grew up in Mennonite country (Waterloo, Ontario) :-)
I am so happy to have finally completed a Saturday!
Thanks Chuck! your puzzle made my day!

cheers all

Itewan is not the place to see anything more than the antique shops. It is a typical, tourist who doesn't want to really be abroad but thinks they do, sort of place. The good of it is they have western sizes. I suggest just winging it. That is how you come across the interesting stuff. See the lived in Hanok village near the palace, Bau House cafe, dog cafe in Hapjeong, the parks, fish market, the tower is only so, so you see as much from the bottom as you do from the top without the cost or the wait in line for the elevator. Do the Seoul tour bus gives you a good overall view of the city. Eat at one of the tented make shift looking places, great food to be had if you can decipher the menu.

We dined here on 01/07/2010 and loved it.  The atmosphere is so tranquil; it is a welcome break from the busy city.  We ordered vegetarian and chicken hot and sour soup, tofu broccoli stir fry, vegetable noodles, roast mutton, red curry chicken, and oatmeal and missie roti.  The soup was our favorite.  If you are in Banjara Hills, go.

I really thought there were two 'L"s in Marshal.  That there is only one is the lesson I will probably retain from today's puzzle.  Congratulations Patricia!  This was also my first Saturday solve without help.  I was able to work out the ones I didn't know on the crosses rather than peeking at this page.
'We have met the enemy and he is us!'
Yikes. Guns = death. I stay far away from them and US foreign policy.

Should we, as the guys from Cambridge and Maine suggest, throw unicorns and rainbows at our enemies? It is my experience that there is in fact evil in the world and good intentions are vastly inferior to small arms in guarding against it.

"NATO 7.62 ball ammunition is too a small caliber for this kind of fight. The .45 caliber pistol was developed for the army for Muslim Moro Insurrection in the Philippines. Charging fanatics couldn't be stopped by smaller caliber ammunition."

Just informing the readers that the M4/M16 use the 5.56 mm caliber which is significantly smaller and less powerful than the 7.62 mm round. However, the 7.62 round is significantly more powerful than a .45.

"With M16 and M1 the army could improve results with the 7.62 by using hollow point rather than ball ammunition,"

The Hague convention strictly prohibits the usage of expanding bullets in warfare. Of course, our enemies don't seem to adhere to the Hague convention.

It was necessary for Mr. Asif Ali Zardari to hit back because this is only the language we people understand. As far as the issue of corruption is concerned then All Government Departments are suffering from the Cancer. The Heads and Tails of All Political Parties are corrupt. Just visit any department, you can't get your work done unless you grease their palms. Recruitment/Promotions in almost all departments have nothing to do with "Merit". Religious Intolerance is on its PEAK. The Most Corrupt of not way back long are now appearing in Saintly Cloths. Who will clean this Mess ?  Taliban - No, Army - Never &No, Religious Party - of course No, Judges - Main Culprits who gave life to all dictators - No, then Who ...?  I hope someone from some where between us will appear some day. I hope it is not toooooo late. This country was not created for loot and plunder. We need Big Change of Mind Set.

Most of the comments here show a high level of ignorance and are just repeating myths they've heard/read elsewhere.

The M4/M16 is highly reliable. I know of rifles that have gone 3,000, 5,000 and even 25,000+ rounds with no cleaning whatsoever, just lubrication, and they still shoot great. But, it's a mechanical device with physical limitations and parts that have defined service lives. Run enough ammo through any rifle in a short time and you will destroy the barrel. That's just physics. It's not a deficiency of the design.

If parts are left to run past their service lives they will break. Colt makes some of the best bolts out there, but if you don't replace them (poor maintenance) they'll eventually break.

When failures occur (such as the ones at Wanat) everyone is quick to blame it on the design of the rifle without bothering to understand what actually happened.

As far as lethality goes, you can kill a human with a .22 if you hit them in the right place. If you hit a person in a vital region they will go down. If you don't, they won't, even with .308 or .30-06. There's no magic bullet that will kill any person with a single shot no matter where it hits.

Regarding the AK, it's a good platform. But it is not as accurate as the M4/M16 at long ranges, and it has limited options for mounting optics and other accessories that our soldiers/marines require today.
This is really one of the best no-nonsense charcoal broiled burgers in the country.  Also some of the best onion rings.  The vibe--eating outdoors in paradise--gives it the last half-star.

The guy is a complete tool.
I loved watching Darelle Revis smack him around.

10A was especially tricky, considering within the sports of tennis and golf it could have been VENUS Williams, TIGER WOODS, or MARAT SAFIN! So even googling didn't prove a gimme...

My first "I'm sure without even counting squares" answer was 53A. Child of the 80's.
I like Ochocinco. I thought it was cool that he kicked the extra point during one of the preseason games. They should let him kick in a real game someday.
I do theatre trips to NYC and always make two stops mandatory.  Virgil's (best brisket) and Scarlottos (best handmade meatballs)all withing the theatre district......44th and 47th respectively.

I'm mountaineer from WA always got lost and went away from the good events arranged by NYC and without intention, I always forgot the direction where I was from, this I refers city maps not fine available on the streets and the signs I was passing were hidden by the signs of the buildings nearby. Thank god I received assistance from the patrol in unuform that I could return to my hotel room safe.

This one felt like a Wednesday or, at worst, a Thursday job to me. Odd how that happens. I don't think it has much to do with the solver's intelligence, but, rather, depends on a rare combination of 1) more clues than usual that the solver just happens to know, 2) a rare and brief tendency of the brain instantly to comprehend misdirection clues exactly as the constructor meant them, and 3) perhaps just a touch of lightness to the puzzle, Saturday notwithstanding. Whatever the exact explanation in this case, color me delighted. Yes, a killer puzzle builds character, but to be able to rip through a Saturday entry is good for the soul.

I used the M16A1 in the military, and as I recall the specified sustained rate of fire was 12 to 15 rounds per minute, not much different than other rifles that were available. ‘Matty Mattel’ was easier to shoot than an M1 Garand or an M14, evident by the number of personnel who were able to quality as expert rifleman on the known distance range, which at the time was out to 500 yards. 5.56 is also much lighter than 30.06 or .308 ammo, where each round of 30.06 weighs around one ounce. After the military I enjoyed shooting ‘high power rifle’ for awhile, where one engages 10 pt targets out to 600 yards. I would occasionally see someone show up at a shoot with an AK47 / SKS, but they’d almost always quit at the 300 yard line as they couldn’t hit anything.

To be effective with something like an M14 one needs a lot more training as the recoil requires tighter positions for semi-auto fire. The training is required as one is forced to carry less of the heavier ammo, so each round needs to count, at least count more. Hits count, not rounds fired, something evident by how a good rifleman / sniper can pin down a larger unit. As others have mentioned we’re talking about what is the best all around compromise for a rifle, and with the M16A1 it was recognized that a heavier round was needed to engage troops at distance. The M16A2 with a heavier, slower bullet was a result, and the heavier barrel could withstand higher rates of sustained fire. It was interesting to see that with the M16A2 we ended up with a rifle that weighed almost as much as M14 and had a round that had a muzzle velocity similar to that used in the M14. The M4 appears to be reaction to the length and weight, and we seemed to end up with something similar to M1 Carbine / M1 Garand differences in firepower, although the differences are a lot less as the same ammo is used in the M16A2 and M4.

The M16 needs more care regarding cleaning, cleaning techniques need to vary with temperature and conditions, and magazines and ammo need to be kept clean too.

If Carroll gets full control of football operations in Seattle, will he have the uniforms redesigned?  Sure hope so.  He'll be going from one of the sharpest-clad teams in the country to one wearing outfits that look like off-color wet suits.

Texas and Florida are ranked too high.

Teams w/ 1st year starters at the QB position usually struggle a bit (the exception being if the 1st year starter is an upperclassman).
The McCoy comments during postgame interview showed the humility and acceptance of the events that are a lesson for all. No evidence of victimization.

Nobody is even mentioning Oklahoma?  All but one position (CB) will be manned by someone that saw significant starting time this year.  The great thing about an injury-laden season is the ability to put younger talent on the fast track.  They also have one of the top incoming classes in the country (Scout #1, Rivals #3).  Preseason rating won't matter too much, I guess, as we will know what this team is made of early.  The Sooners will boast what is, probably, the toughest non-conference schedule in the country.  Utah St. (gotta have at least one of these), Florida St.,Air Force, and Cincinnati.  If you ask me, it looks like the Big XII Championship could have an old school Battle of the Big Reds!!

The truth is that the Rangers should have played the Bruins this year at Fenway. Two original 6 teams with a history of rivalry back in the better days....
So do it next year in the NY metro area.

2nd choice- Canadiens vs. the Leafs- can't get much better rivalry than that!
